author: ralexstokes
content: Re: syncing, let‚Äôs assume you have some recent information from the chain you care to sync, like a recent finalized hash (this could be bc you have stayed in sync w/ the validator set inside the weak subjectivity period, or because you got the data external to the protocol outside the weak subjectivity period)

author: terence0083
content: correct, this question is for syncing to the latest finalized hash : )

author: ralexstokes
content: Given the recent info, you would basically download a peers chain from slots 0-100, verifying the header chain along the way

author: ralexstokes
content: Once you get to the data you trust, you can verify the header chain is valid and yields the data you have

author: ralexstokes
content: Eg comparing state roots

author: ralexstokes
content: As long as we can trust our hash assumptions, I don‚Äôt see a need to verify other stuff along the way

author: ralexstokes
content: There is a separate question of state syncing and I‚Äôve been eyeing Jason Carver‚Äôs work on eth1 beam sync for that

author: ralexstokes
content: https://link.medium.com/2tXzZlogh0

author: ralexstokes
content: It should be noted the above strategy could get you called a ‚Äúlazy node‚Äù, h/t ‚Äúthe validators dilemma‚Äù

author: ralexstokes
content: So you could think about doing deeper verification, possibly in some low prio BG task to (spot) check the chain

author: ralexstokes
content: Once you have synced the finalized head you have, you can then turn into ‚Äúhead following‚Äù mode where you gossip stuff, build the chain tip, etc like usual

author: terence0083
content: Yep yep! thanks!

author: terence0083
content: The 3 biggest bottleneck for downloading a peers chain from slots 0-100 are 1.) verifying proposer signature, 2.) verifying randao 3.) verifying attestations aggregation signature

author: terence0083
content: I think we can safely say to discard all 3 operaitons

author: terence0083
content: and just verify the state root as you are getting closer to the head

author: ralexstokes
content: Depends on your security model, the above is my consideration of the ‚Äúminimal‚Äù work you can do and still sync the right chain ‚Äî it kind of makes you a light client while syncing so in theory the network loses some ‚Äúherd immunity‚Äù you get from having more (rather than fewer) full nodes in eth1

author: terence0083
content: Ok cool, we'll def take that into consideration

author: terence0083
content: thank you!
